original.title: Book IX: The Tyrannical Soul
original.preview: Socrates: Last of all comes the tyrannical man; about whom we have yet to enquire, how he is formed out of the democratical character.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Last of all comes the tyrannical man; about whom we have yet to enquire, how he is formed out of the democratical character, and what manner of man he is, and whether his life is happy or miserable.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, he is the only one remaining.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There is, however, a previous question which remains unanswered. What is the nature and number of the appetites? This must first be determined.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Well, it is not too late to supply the omission.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Certain of the unnecessary pleasures and appetites I conceive to be unlawful; every one appears to have them, but in some persons they are controlled by the laws and by reason, and the better desires prevail over them.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Which appetites do you mean?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I mean those which are awake when the reasoning and human and ruling power is asleep; then the wild beast within us, gorged with meat or drink, starts up and having shaken off sleep, goes forth to satisfy his desires.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And there is no conceivable folly or crime—not excepting incest or any other unnatural union, or parricide, or the eating of forbidden food—which at such a time, when he has parted company with all shame and sense, a man may not be ready to commit.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Most true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But when a man's pulse is healthy and temperate, and when before going to sleep he has awakened his rational powers, and fed them on noble thoughts and enquiries, collecting himself in meditation, then he attains truth most nearly, and is least likely to be the sport of fantastic and lawless visions.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I quite agree.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: In saying this I have been running into a digression; but the point which I desire to note is that in all of us, even in good men, there is a lawless wild-beast nature, which peers out in sleep.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, I agree.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And now remember the character which we attributed to the democratic man. He was supposed from his youth upwards to have been trained under a miserly parent, who encouraged the saving appetites in him, but discountenanced the unnecessary.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And then he got into the company of a more refined, licentious sort of people, and taking to all their wanton ways rushed into the opposite extreme. At last, being a better man than his corruptors, he was drawn in both directions until he halted midway.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, that was our view of him, and is so still.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And now, years will have passed away, and you must conceive this man, such as he is, to have a son, who is brought up in his father's principles.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I can imagine him.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then you must further imagine the same thing to happen to the son which has already happened to the father: he is drawn into a perfectly lawless life, which by his seducers is termed perfect liberty.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: As soon as these dire magicians and tyrant-makers find that they are losing their hold on him, they contrive to implant in him a master passion, to be lord over his idle and spendthrift lusts—a sort of monstrous winged drone.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, that is the only adequate image of him.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And when his other lusts, amid clouds of incense and perfumes and garlands and wines, and all the pleasures of a dissolute life, now let loose, come buzzing around him, then at last this lord of the soul, having Madness for the captain of his guard, breaks out into a frenzy.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, that is the way in which the tyrannical man is generated.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And is not this the reason why of old love has been called a tyrant?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I should not wonder.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Further, has not a drunken man also the spirit of a tyrant?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: He has.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And you know that a man who is deranged and not right in his mind, will fancy that he is able to rule, not only over men, but also over the gods?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That he will.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the tyrannical man in the true sense of the word comes into being when, either under the influence of nature, or habit, or both, he becomes drunken, lustful, passionate.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Assuredly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Such is the man and such is his origin. And next, how does he live?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Suppose, as people facetiously say, you were to tell me.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I imagine that in the next place there will be feasts and carousals and revellings and courtezans, and all that sort of thing; Love is the lord of the house within him, and orders all the concerns of his soul.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That is certain.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yes; and every day and every night desires grow up many and formidable, and their demands are many.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: They are indeed.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: His revenues, if he has any, are soon spent. Then comes debt and the cutting down of his property.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Of course.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When he has nothing left, must not his desires, crowding in the nest like young ravens, be crying aloud for food; and he, goaded on by them, is in a frenzy, and would fain discover whom he can defraud or despoil of his property?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, that is sure to be the case.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: He must have money, no matter how, if he is to escape horrid pains and pangs.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: He must.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if his parents will not give way, then he will try first of all to cheat and deceive them.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if he fails, then he will use force and plunder them.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, probably.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if the old man and woman fight for their own, what then, my friend? Will the creature feel any compunction at tyrannizing over them?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Nay, I should not feel at all comfortable about his parents.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But, O heavens! Adeimantus, on account of some newfangled love of a harlot, can you believe that he would strike the mother who is his ancient friend and necessary to his very existence?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, indeed, I believe that he would.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Truly, then, a tyrannical son is a blessing to his father and mother.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: He is indeed.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: He first takes their property, and when that falls, and pleasures are beginning to swarm in the hive of his soul, then he breaks into a house, or steals the garments of some nightly wayfarer; next he proceeds to clear a temple.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Meanwhile the old opinions which he had when a child, and which gave judgment about good and evil, are overthrown by those others which have just been emancipated, and are now the bodyguard of love.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, indeed.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if there are only a few of them in the State, the rest of the people are well disposed, they go away and become the bodyguard or mercenary soldiers of some other tyrant who may probably want them for a war.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: What sort of mischief do they cause if there is no war?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: They are the thieves, burglars, cutpurses, footpads, robbers of temples, man-stealers of the community; or if they are able to speak they turn informers, and bear false witness, and take bribes.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: A small catalogue of evils, even if the perpetrators of them are few in number.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When this noxious class and their followers grow numerous and become conscious of their strength, assisted by the infatuation of the people, they choose from among themselves the one who has most of the tyrant in his own soul, and him they create their tyrant.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, and he will be the most fit to be a tyrant.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: If the people yield, well and good; but if they resist him, as he began by beating his own father and mother, so now, if he has the power, he beats them, and will keep his dear old fatherland or motherland in subjection to his young retainers.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Exactly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: They are always either the masters or servants and never the friends of anybody; the tyrant never tastes of true freedom or friendship.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Certainly not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And may we not rightly call such men treacherous? Also they are utterly unjust, if we were right in our notion of justice?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, and we were perfectly right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let us then sum up in a word: the character of the worst man is the waking reality of what we dreamed.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Most true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And this is he who being by nature most of a tyrant bears rule, and the longer he lives the more of a tyrant he becomes.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That is certain.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And will not he who has been shown to be the wickedest, be also the most miserable? And he who has tyrannized longest and most, most continually and truly miserable?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, inevitably.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And must not the tyrannical man be like the tyrannical State, and the democratical man like the democratical State; and the same of the others?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And as State is to State in virtue and happiness, so is man in relation to man?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: To be sure.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then comparing our original city, which was under a king, and the city which is under a tyrant, how do they stand as to virtue?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: They are the opposite extremes, for one is the very best and the other is the very worst.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I will at once enquire whether you would arrive at a similar decision about their relative happiness and misery. And here we must not be panic-stricken at the apparition of the tyrant, who is only a unit and may perhaps have a few retainers about him.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: A fair invitation; and I see, as every one must, that a tyranny is the wretchedest form of government, and the rule of a king the happiest.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: May I suppose that the judgment is given by one who is able to judge, and has dwelt in the same place with him, and been present at his daily life and known him in his family relations, where he may be seen stripped of his tragedy attire?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That again is a very fair proposal.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Beginning with the State: would you say that a city which is governed by a tyrant is free or enslaved?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: No city can be more completely enslaved.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And yet, as you see, there are freemen as well as masters in such a State?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, I see that there are—a few; but the people, speaking generally, and the best of them, are miserably degraded and enslaved.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then if the man is like the State, must not the same rule prevail? His soul is full of meanness and vulgarity—the best elements in him are enslaved; and there is a small ruling part, which is also the worst and maddest.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Inevitably.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And would you say that the soul of such an one is the soul of a freeman, or of a slave?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: He has the soul of a slave, in my opinion.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And also the soul which is under a tyrant is least capable of doing what she desires; there is a gadfly which goads her, and she is full of trouble and remorse?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And is the city which is under a tyrant rich or poor?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Poor.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the tyrannical soul must be always poor and insatiable?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And must not such a State and such a man be always full of fear?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, indeed.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Is there any State in which you will find more of lamentation and sorrow and groaning and pain?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly not.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Reflecting upon these and similar evils, you held the tyrannical State to be the most miserable of States?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: And I was right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Certainly. And when you see the same evils in the tyrannical man, what do you say of him?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I say that he is by far the most miserable of all men.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There, I think that you are beginning to go wrong.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What do you mean?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I do not think that he has as yet reached the utmost extreme of misery.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Then who is more miserable?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: He who is of a tyrannical nature, and instead of leading a private life has been cursed with the further misfortune of being a public tyrant.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: From what has been said, I gather that you are right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The case of rich individuals in cities who possess many slaves may form an idea of the tyrant's condition, for they both have slaves; the only difference is that he has more slaves.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, that is the difference.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You know that they live securely and have nothing to apprehend from their servants?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What should they fear?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Nothing. But do you observe the reason of this? The whole city is leagued together for the protection of each individual.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But imagine one of these owners, the master say of some fifty slaves, together with his family and property and slaves, carried off by a god into the wilderness, where there are no freemen to help him—will he not be in an agony of fear lest he and his wife and children should be put to death by his slaves?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, he will be in the utmost fear.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And is not this the sort of prison in which the tyrant will be bound—he who being by nature such as we have described, is full of all sorts of fears and lusts? His soul is dainty and greedy, and yet alone, of all men in the city, he is never allowed to go on a journey, or to see the things which other freemen desire to see.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: He who is the real tyrant, whatever men may think, is the real slave, and is obliged to practise the greatest adulation and servility, and to be the flatterer of the vilest of mankind.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: He has desires which he is utterly unable to satisfy, and has more wants than any one, and is truly poor, if you know how to inspect the whole soul of him: all his life long he is beset with fear and is full of convulsions and distractions.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Moreover, he grows worse from having power: he becomes and is of necessity more jealous, more faithless, more unjust, more friendless, more impious, than he was at first; he is the purveyor and cherisher of every sort of vice.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: No man of any sense will dispute your words.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Come then, as the general umpire in theatrical contests proclaims the result, do you also decide who in your opinion is first in the scale of happiness, and who second, and in what order the others follow: there are five of them in all—they are the royal, timocratical, oligarchical, democratical, tyrannical.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: The decision will be easily given: they shall be choruses coming on the stage, and I must judge them in the order in which they enter, by the criterion of virtue and vice, happiness and misery.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Need we hire a herald, or shall I announce, that the son of Ariston has decided that the best and justest is also the happiest, and that this is he who is the most royal man and king over himself?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Make the proclamation yourself.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And shall I add, 'whether seen or unseen by gods and men'?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Let the words be added.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then this will be our first proof; and there is another, which may also have some weight.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What is that?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The second proof is derived from the nature of the soul: seeing that the individual soul, like the State, has been divided by us into three principles, the division may furnish a new demonstration.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Of what nature?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: It seems to me that to these three principles three pleasures correspond; also three desires and governing powers.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: How do you mean?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There is one principle with which a man learns, another with which he is angry; the third, having many forms, has no special name, but is denoted by the general term appetitive, from the extraordinary strength of the desires of eating and drinking.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That is true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: If we were to say that the loves and pleasures of this third part were concerned with gain, we should then be able to fall back on a single notion; and might truly describe this part of the soul as loving gain or money.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I agree with you.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Again, is not the passionate element wholly set on ruling and conquering and getting fame?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: On the other hand, every one sees that the principle of knowledge is wholly directed to the truth, and cares less than either of the others for gain or fame.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Far less.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then we may begin by assuming that there are three classes of men—lovers of wisdom, lovers of honour, lovers of gain?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Exactly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And there are three kinds of pleasure, which are their several objects?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now, if you examine the three classes of men, and ask of them in turn which of their lives is pleasantest, each will be found praising his own and depreciating that of others.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Since, then, the pleasures of each class and the life of each are in dispute, and the question is not which life is more or less honourable, or better or worse, but which is the more pleasant or painless—how shall we know who speaks truly?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I cannot myself tell.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Well, but what ought to be the criterion? Is any better than experience and wisdom and reason?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: There cannot be a better.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then reflect: of the three individuals, which has the greatest experience of all the pleasures which we enumerated? Has the lover of gain, in learning the nature of essential truth, greater experience of the pleasure of knowledge than the philosopher has of the pleasure of gain?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: The philosopher has greatly the advantage; for he has of necessity always known the taste of the other pleasures from his childhood upwards.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then the lover of wisdom has a great advantage over the lover of gain, for he has a double experience?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, very great.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And reasoning is peculiarly the philosopher's instrument?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But since experience and wisdom and reason are the judges—the only inference possible is that pleasures which are approved by the lover of wisdom and reason are the truest.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Unquestionably, the wise man speaks with authority when he approves of his own life.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And so we arrive at the result, that the pleasure of the intelligent part of the soul is the pleasantest of the three, and that he of us in whom this is the ruling principle has the pleasantest life.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What does the judge affirm to be the life which is next, and the pleasure which is next?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Clearly that of the soldier and lover of honour; who is nearer to himself than the money-maker.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Last comes the lover of gain?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Very true. Twice in succession, then, has the just man overthrown the unjust in this conflict; and now comes the third trial, which is dedicated to Olympian Zeus the saviour.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: A sage whispers in my ear that no pleasure except that of the wise is quite true and pure—all others are a shadow only; and surely this will prove the greatest and most decisive of falls?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, the greatest; but will you explain yourself?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Say, then, is not pleasure opposed to pain? And there is a neutral state which is neither pleasure nor pain?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: There is.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You remember what people say when they are sick? That after all nothing is pleasanter than health. But then they never knew this to be the greatest of pleasures until they were ill.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, I know.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: This is an appearance only and not a reality; these representations, when tried by the test of true pleasure, are not real but a sort of imposition.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That is the inference.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Those then who know not wisdom and virtue, and are always busy with gluttony and sensuality, go down and up again as far as the mean; and in this region they move at random throughout life.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But they never pass into the true upper world; thither they neither look, nor do they ever find their way, neither are they truly filled with true being, nor do they taste of pure and abiding pleasure.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Verily, Socrates, you describe the life of the many like an oracle.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And when the whole soul follows the philosophical principle, and there is no division, the several parts are just, and do each of them their own business, and enjoy severally the best and truest pleasures of which they are capable.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Exactly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But when either of the two other principles prevails, it fails in attaining its own pleasure, and compels the rest to pursue after a pleasure which is a shadow only and which is not their own.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then the tyrant will live at the greatest distance from true or natural pleasure, and the king at the least?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But if so, the tyrant will live most unpleasantly, and the king most pleasantly?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Inevitably.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Would you know the measure of the interval which separates them?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Will you tell me?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I assume that the tyrant is in the third place from the oligarch; the democrat was in the middle. And if there is truth in what has preceded, he will be wedded to an image of pleasure which is thrice removed from the pleasure of the oligarch.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: He will.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the oligarch is third from the royal; since we count as one royal and aristocratical.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, he is third.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then the tyrant is removed from true pleasure by the space of a number which is three times three?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Manifestly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if you raise the power and make the plane a solid, there is no difficulty in seeing how vast is the interval by which the tyrant is parted from the king.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes; the arithmetician will easily do the sum.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Or if some person begins at the other end and measures the interval by which the king is parted from the tyrant in truth of pleasure, he will find him, when the multiplication is complete, living 729 times more pleasantly, and the tyrant more painfully by this same interval.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What a wonderful calculation! And how enormous is the distance which separates the just from the unjust in regard to pleasure and pain!

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yet a true calculation, and a number which nearly concerns human life, if human beings are concerned with days and nights and months and years.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, human life is certainly concerned with them.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then if the good and just man be thus superior in pleasure to the evil and unjust, his superiority will be infinitely greater in propriety of life and in beauty and virtue?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Immeasurably greater.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now then, having determined the power and quality of justice and injustice, let us have a little conversation with him who maintains that injustice is a gain to the perfectly unjust.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What shall we say to him?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let us make an image of the soul, that he may have his own words presented before his eyes. An ideal image like the composite creations of ancient mythology, such as the Chimera or Scylla or Cerberus.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: There are said to have been such unions.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then model the form of a multitudinous, many-headed monster, having a ring of heads of all manner of beasts, tame and wild, which he is able to generate and metamorphose at will.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: You suppose marvellous powers in the artist; but, as language is more pliable than wax, let there be such a model as you propose.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Suppose now that you make a second form as of a lion, and a third of a man, the second smaller than the first, and the third smaller than the second.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That is an easier task; and I have made them as you say.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And now join them, and let the three grow into one. Next fashion the outside of them into a single image, as of a man, so that he who sees only the outer hull may believe the beast to be a single human creature.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I have done so.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: To him the supporter of justice makes answer that he should ever so speak and act as to give the man within him the most complete mastery over the entire human creature. He should watch over the many-headed monster like a good husbandman, fostering the gentle qualities, and preventing the wild ones from growing.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, that is quite what the maintainer of justice says.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And so from every point of view, whether of pleasure, honour, or advantage, the approver of justice is right and speaks the truth, and the disapprover is wrong and false and ignorant.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, from every point of view.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What shall he profit, if his injustice be undetected and unpunished? He who is undetected only gets worse, whereas he who is detected and punished has the brutal part of his nature silenced and humanized; the gentler element in him is liberated.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: To this nobler purpose the man of understanding will devote the energies of his life. And in the first place, he will honour studies which impress these qualities on his soul and disregard others.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Clearly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And for the same reason, he will gladly accept and enjoy such honours as he deems likely to make him a better man; but those, whether private or public, which are likely to disorder his life, he will avoid.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Then, if that is his motive, he will not be a statesman.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: By the dog of Egypt, he will! In the city which is his own he certainly will, though in the land of his birth perhaps not, unless he have a divine call.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I understand; you mean that he will be a ruler in the city of which we are the founders, and which exists in idea only; for I do not believe that there is such an one anywhere on earth.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: In heaven there is laid up a pattern of it, methinks, which he who desires may behold, and beholding, may set his own house in order. But whether such an one exists, or ever will exist in fact, is no matter; for he will live after the manner of that city, having nothing to do with any other.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I think so.

modern.title: Book IX: The Tyrant Within
modern.preview: Socrates: Finally, let's examine the tyrannical person—how they develop from the democratic type, and whether they're happy or miserable.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Finally, let's examine the tyrannical person—how they develop from the democratic type, and whether they're happy or miserable.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Right, they're the only one left.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But first we need to understand desire. What is it, and how many kinds are there?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Agreed.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Some pleasures and desires are lawful, others are lawless. The lawless ones exist in everyone—even good people—but in them they're kept in check by reason and social norms.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: What kind of desires are you talking about?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The ones that wake up when our rational mind sleeps. That's when the wild beast inside us—stuffed with food and drink—roams free, shameless and unrestrained.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There's no crime too horrific—incest, murder, anything—that a person won't consider when their reason is asleep and their shame is gone.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's absolutely true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But when someone is healthy and moderate, and goes to sleep after engaging their rational mind with good thoughts, they're more likely to have truthful dreams.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I agree completely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I'm getting sidetracked, but here's the point: everyone—even good people—has a wild, lawless nature that reveals itself in dreams.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, I agree.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now, the democratic person. They were raised by a stingy parent who encouraged saving and discouraged unnecessary pleasures.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then they met more sophisticated people full of intense passions. Pulled in both directions, they found a middle ground.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: They enjoyed various pleasures in moderation, avoiding extremes. That's how the oligarchic person became democratic.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That was our analysis.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now imagine this person has a son raised the same way—but the son gets pulled toward lawlessness, which his corrupters call 'freedom.'

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Naturally.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Turns out he has a whole class of fierce desires that his father's discipline and his own shame had kept hidden.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That makes sense.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When these manipulators have drained him dry, they plant a master passion in him—like a giant drone that rules over all his idle, wasteful desires.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's the perfect metaphor for him.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: His other desires buzz around him like bees, feeding on pleasures, incense, perfumes, parties—intensifying the sting of desire in his drone-like soul.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Finally, this master passion—with Madness as its bodyguard—goes crazy. If any good impulses or shame remain, it destroys them.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's exactly how the tyrannical person develops.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Isn't this why love has always been called a tyrant?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Wouldn't surprise me.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And drunk people have the same tyrannical spirit.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: They do.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: A deranged person thinks they can rule not just humans, but even the gods.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Definitely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The true tyrannical person emerges when nature, habit, or both make them drunk on lust and passion.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Absolutely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: That's who they are and how they develop. Now, how do they live?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: You tell me.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I imagine endless parties, drinking, hookups. Desire is the master of their house, controlling everything.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: For sure.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Every day and night, new desires grow stronger and more demanding.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: They really do.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Whatever money they have gets spent fast.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then comes debt and selling off their stuff. When there's nothing left, their desires scream for more like hungry baby birds in a nest.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Exactly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Driven mad by desire—especially by obsessive love—they're ready to do anything. Steal, break into houses, pick pockets.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: They have to.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: If their elderly parents won't give them money, they'll try to trick them first.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if that fails, they'll use force.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I'd expect so.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if the old folks fight back? Would they hesitate to become tyrants over their own parents?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I wouldn't bet on those parents' safety.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Think about it—for some new fling, they'd abuse the mother who raised them? For some new friend, they'd attack their aged father?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, I believe they would.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What miserable luck to have a tyrannical child.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Truly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When their parents' resources run out, they'll turn to crime. At first, small stuff. Then bigger.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Obviously.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: If no one stops them, they'll graduate to violence—robbery, kidnapping, temple-robbing. All those childhood fantasies become reality.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Naturally.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When there are many such people in a city who find each other, and they have followers, they'll create a tyrant—whoever has the biggest, most tyrannical soul.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Makes sense—they'd be the most tyrannical.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: If people submit willingly, great. If not, the tyrant punishes the city like they punished their parents. The city becomes a slave.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's definitely where it leads.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Tyrannical people are always either masters or servants—never friends. They never experience true freedom or friendship.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Can we call them anything other than treacherous? And completely unjust, if our definition of justice was correct?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Our definition was correct.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let's sum up: the worst person is someone who lives out the nightmares we only have in dreams. The longer they hold power, the worse they become.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That's certain.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And won't the most wicked person also be the most miserable? And the one who's been a tyrant longest, most completely miserable?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Inevitably.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The tyrannical person must be like the tyrannical state, and the democratic person like the democratic state, and so on.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: As state is to state in virtue and happiness, so person is to person.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Exactly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So comparing our ideal city under a philosopher-king with a city under a tyrant—how do they compare in virtue?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: They're polar opposites. One is the best, the other the worst.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let's examine their relative happiness. Don't be intimidated by the tyrant's power—he's just one person with a few followers. Let's look at his whole life.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Fair enough. Everyone can see that tyranny is the most wretched form of government, and monarchy the happiest.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Would you say a city under a tyrant is free or enslaved?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Completely enslaved.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But there are some free people and masters in such a state?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: A few. But the majority, including the best people, are miserably enslaved.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: If the person mirrors the state, the same must be true of their soul—it's full of slavery, with the best parts enslaved to the worst, maddest part.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Inevitably.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Would you say such a soul is free or enslaved?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Enslaved, definitely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The tyrannical soul can't do what it truly wants. It's constantly goaded by desire, full of turmoil and regret.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Is a tyrannical state rich or poor?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Poor.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So the tyrannical soul must always be poor and insatiable.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And full of fear?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Absolutely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Is there any state with more grief, more sorrow, more pain?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: None.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So you'd say the tyrannical state is the most miserable?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I was right about that.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the tyrannical person?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: By far the most miserable of all.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Actually, I think you're not going far enough.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What do you mean?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There's someone even more miserable: the tyrannical person who actually becomes a public tyrant.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That follows logically.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Think about wealthy slaveholders. They feel secure because the whole city protects them. But imagine one transported to the wilderness with just their slaves—they'd be terrified of being killed.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: They'd be in extreme fear.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: That's the tyrant's prison. Full of fears and desires, they can never travel freely or see what other free people see. They live hidden away, suspicious of everyone.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The real tyrant, whatever people think, is the real slave. They must flatter the worst people, can never satisfy their desires, and are truly the poorest of all. Their whole life is fear and torment.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That's a powerful picture.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And power makes them worse: more jealous, faithless, unjust, friendless, and impious. They become the source of every vice, and make everyone around them miserable.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: No sensible person would disagree.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So as the final judge, rank the five types—royal, timocratic, oligarchic, democratic, and tyrannical—by happiness.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Easy. I'll judge them by virtue, vice, happiness, and misery as they come on stage.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Should I announce the verdict? The son of Ariston declares: the best and most just person is also the happiest—the one who is most kingly and rules themselves. The worst and most unjust is the most miserable—the tyrant over themselves and their state.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Announce it yourself.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Should I add: 'whether seen or unseen by gods and humans'?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Add it.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: That's our first proof. Here's the second, based on the soul's three parts.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Go on.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Three parts of the soul means three kinds of pleasure and three kinds of desire. One part learns, one gets angry, and one—the appetitive part—craves food, drink, and sensual pleasures, which generally require money.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The spirited part seeks power, victory, and fame. The rational part seeks truth and wisdom.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Exactly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So there are three types of people: lovers of wisdom, lovers of honor, and lovers of money. Each thinks their pleasure is best.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But who's the best judge? Experience, wisdom, and reason should decide. And who has experienced all three pleasures? The philosopher has tasted wealth and honor, but the money-lover and honor-seeker have never experienced philosophical joy.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: The philosopher has the fullest experience.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the philosopher uses reason—the proper tool for judgment. So their verdict is most trustworthy.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Necessarily.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Wisdom's pleasures are truest and best, followed by honor, then money. The tyrant, enslaved to the lowest desires, is furthest from true pleasure.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Clearly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now for the third and greatest proof: only the philosopher's pleasure is pure and true. Other pleasures are merely shadows.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: The greatest? Explain.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Pleasure is opposed to pain, with a neutral state between. When sick people feel healthy, they say nothing beats health—but they didn't appreciate it until they were ill.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, I've seen that.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: That's not real pleasure—it's just relief from pain. Real pleasure exists independently. Most bodily pleasures are like this—fake.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I follow.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: People who know only physical pleasures wander between pain and neutral, thinking neutral is pleasure. Like cattle, they graze, breed, and fight over these shadow pleasures, never looking up to true pleasure.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: You're describing most people's lives like an oracle.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When the soul follows philosophy as its guide and is unified, each part does its job and enjoys the truest pleasure available to it.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Exactly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But when other parts take control, they chase pleasures that aren't truly theirs—shadows of pleasure.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So the tyrant lives farthest from true pleasure, and the philosopher-king closest?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The tyrant lives most unpleasantly, the king most pleasantly?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Inevitably.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Want to know the exact measure of the difference?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Tell me.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The tyrant is three places from the oligarch, with the democrat in the middle. So their pleasure is three times removed. And the oligarch is three from the king. So: three times three equals nine.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Makes sense.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Cube it—nine times nine times nine. The king lives 729 times more pleasantly than the tyrant!

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What an incredible calculation! The gap between just and unjust is enormous!

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And it's a true number, relating to days and nights in a human life.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Human life is definitely measured that way.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: If the just person beats the unjust so decisively in pleasure, imagine how much greater their advantage in living well and beautifully.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Immeasurably greater.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let's imagine the soul as a mythical creature—like Chimera or Cerberus—a many-headed monster of tame and wild beasts, plus a lion, plus a human. The human is smallest.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I can picture it.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now wrap them in human skin so they look like a single person. Those who praise injustice are feeding the monster and lion while starving the human. Justice means letting the human control everything, taming the beasts.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That's exactly what justice means.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Even if the unjust escape punishment, they're still punished by their own corrupted soul. But if caught and reformed, the brutal part is humanized and the gentle part freed.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Clearly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The wise person will devote their life to cultivating justice and wisdom, not chasing money or honor for their own sake.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: If that's their goal, they won't go into politics.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Oh, they will—in their own city, the one inside them. Maybe not in their birthplace, unless fate intervenes.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I understand—you mean the city we've been building in words. It exists in heaven as a pattern for anyone who wants to see it and create that order in themselves. Whether it exists on earth doesn't matter.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Exactly. They'll live by its principles, no other city's.
